How do we accommodate users with specific disabilities, such as visual, auditory, or neurodivergent conditions?
How does AI and machine learning influence accessibility tools and resources?
How can I ensure my materials are compatible with speech-to-text software and other assistive technologies?

What information does a screen reader provide about a list?
What types of assistive technologies support students in higher education?

How do I balance design with accessibility?
How can haptic feedback in devices be designed to be accessible?
How can physical sensory characteristics be considered and used?
How do I ensure accessibility in interactive media like virtual reality (VR) or augmented reality (AR)?
How do I make sure my online content works well across various devices, including mobile devices, tablets, and desktop computers?
What is Universal Design for Learning (UDL), and how does it relate to digital accessibility in the context of university courses?
How do I know if I'm meeting accessibility standards for my online courses?

How would you approach a conversation when a faculty member reaches out and says they are not sure how to make their online lectures accessible?
Can you provide an example of how to create accessible content that is also universally designed to be inclusive of all learning styles?
How can I make sure my course materials are accessible from the start, rather than having to retrofit accessibility later in the course design process?
How can we support students with neurodivergent conditions through accessible content design?
How do I make sure to include accessibility through content planning, design, and decision making?

How would you advise a department to make a scanned PDF more accessible?
Can't Excel make accessible tables?
How do I know if my captions meet the requirements?
How do I make sure that images, including decorative ones, are accessible to users with screen readers?

What elements of an online form should a faculty member pay attention to?
How can we make online quizzes and assessments accessible for all students, including those with disabilities?
How do I ensure the accessibility of online event registration forms and systems?
Are there any tools or checklists I can use to ensure compliance?
How do I do manual testing?
Why do I need both automated testing and manual testing?
If a website fails an accessibility audit, what should be the first steps taken to begin remediation?
Can't I just do manual testing then?
What are the best practices for auditing a website or content for accessibility?
What are the limitations of automated accessibility testing tools, and why is manual testing still essential?
What tools are available to check digital accessibility?
How do I evaluate my entire website for accessibility errors?
Does math count as visual content? How do I make it accessible?
How do I make equations and mathematical notation accessible?
Are there times when a list specifically should be used?
Can't users just skim to find what they need?
Explain the difference between buttons and links again. How do I know when to use each one?

How can icon only buttons be made accessible?
How can nested lists be made to be more accessible?

Does all this digital accessibility stuff apply to emails?
Does this limit my academic freedom?
Can a product be usable but not accessible?
